member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory
member.summary: Defines identifiers that represent categories of user preferences.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Accessibility
member.summary: Indicates user preferences associated with accessibility features of the system for users with disabilities.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Color
member.summary: Indicates user preferences associated with system colors. This category includes such as the default color of windows or menus.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Desktop
member.summary: Indicates user preferences associated with the system desktop. This category includes the background image or background image layout of the desktop.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.General
member.summary: Indicates user preferences that are not associated with any other category.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Icon
member.summary: Indicates user preferences for icon settings, including icon height and spacing.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Keyboard
member.summary: Indicates user preferences for keyboard settings, such as the key down repeat rate and delay.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Locale
member.summary: Indicates changes in user preferences for regional settings, such as the character encoding and culture strings.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Menu
member.summary: Indicates user preferences for menu settings, such as menu delays and text alignment.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Mouse
member.summary: Indicates user preferences for mouse settings, such as double-click time and mouse sensitivity.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Policy
member.summary: Indicates user preferences for policy settings, such as user rights and access levels.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Power
member.summary: Indicates the user preferences for system power settings. This category includes power feature settings, such as the idle time before the system automatically enters low power mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Screensaver
member.summary: Indicates user preferences associated with the screensaver.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.VisualStyle
member.summary: Indicates user preferences associated with visual styles, such as enabling or disabling visual styles and switching from one visual style to another.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Win32.UserPreferenceCategory.Window
member.summary: Indicates user preferences associated with the dimensions and characteristics of windows on the system.

member.name: T:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint
member.summary: Specifies values that succinctly describe the results of a masked text parsing operation.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.AlphanumericCharacterExpected
member.summary: Operation did not succeed.An input character was encountered that was not alphanumeric. .

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.AsciiCharacterExpected
member.summary: Operation did not succeed.An input character was encountered that was not a member of the ASCII character set.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.CharacterEscaped
member.summary: Success. The operation succeeded because a literal, prompt or space character was an escaped character. For more information about escaped characters, see the method.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.DigitExpected
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. An input character was encountered that was not a digit.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.InvalidInput
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. The program encountered an input character that was not valid. For more information about characters that are not valid, see the method.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.LetterExpected
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. An input character was encountered that was not a letter.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.NoEffect
member.summary: Success. The primary operation was not performed because it was not needed; therefore, no side effect was produced.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.NonEditPosition
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. The current position in the formatted string is a literal character.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.PositionOutOfRange
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. The specified position is not in the range of the target string; typically it is either less than zero or greater then the length of the target string.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.PromptCharNotAllowed
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. The prompt character is not valid at input, perhaps because the property is set to false.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.SideEffect
member.summary: Success. The primary operation was not performed because it was not needed, but the method produced a side effect. For example, the method can delete an unassigned edit position, which causes left-shifting of subsequent characters in the formatted string.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.SignedDigitExpected
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. An input character was encountered that was not a signed digit.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.Success
member.summary: Success. The primary operation succeeded.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.UnavailableEditPosition
member.summary: Operation did not succeed. There were not enough edit positions available to fulfill the request.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.MaskedTextResultHint.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown. The result of the operation could not be determined.

member.name: T:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes
member.summary: Defines identifiers that indicate the type of a selection.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Add
member.summary: Represents an add selection that adds the selected components to the current selection, maintaining the current set of selected components.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Auto
member.summary: Represents a regular selection. The selection service responds to the CTRL and SHIFT keys to support adding or removing components to or from the selection.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Click
member.summary: Represents a selection that occurs when a user clicks a component. If the newly selected component is already selected, it is promoted to be the primary selected component rather than being canceled.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.MouseDown
member.summary: Represents a selection that occurs when the user presses on the mouse button while the mouse pointer is over a component. If the component under the pointer is already selected, it is promoted to become the primary selected component rather than being canceled.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.MouseUp
member.summary: Represents a selection that occurs when the user releases the mouse button immediately after a component has been selected. If the newly selected component is already selected, it is promoted to be the primary selected component rather than being canceled.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Normal
member.summary: Represents a regular selection. The selection service responds to the CTRL and SHIFT keys to support adding or removing components to or from the selection.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Primary
member.summary: Represents a primary selection that occurs when a user clicks on a component. If a component in the selection list is already selected, the component is promoted to be the primary selection.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Remove
member.summary: Represents a remove selection that removes the selected components from the current selection, maintaining the current set of selected components.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Replace
member.summary: Represents a selection that occurs when the content of a selection is replaced. The selection service replaces the current selection with the replacement.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Toggle
member.summary: Represents a toggle selection that switches between the current selection and the provided selection. If a component is already selected and is passed into with a selection type of , the component selection will be canceled.

member.name: F:System.ComponentModel.Design.SelectionTypes.Valid
member.summary: Identifies the valid selection types as , , , , or .

member.name: P:System.Configuration.SettingsPropertyValue.PropertyValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the object.
member.returns: The value of the object. When this value is set, the property is set to true and is set to false.When a value is first accessed from the property, and if the value was initially stored into the object as a serialized representation using the property, the property will trigger deserialization of the underlying value. As a side effect, the property will be set to true.If this chain of events occurs in ASP.NET, and if an error occurs during the deserialization process, the error is logged using the health-monitoring feature of ASP.NET. By default, this means that deserialization errors will show up in the Application Event Log when running under ASP.NET. If this process occurs outside of ASP.NET, and if an error occurs during deserialization, the error is suppressed, and the remainder of the logic during deserialization occurs. If there is no serialized value to deserialize when the deserialization is attempted, then object will instead attempt to return a default value if one was configured as defined on the associated instance. In this case, if the property was set to either null, or to the string "[null]", then the object will initialize the property to either null for reference types, or to the default value for the associated value type. On the other hand, if property holds a valid object reference or string value (other than "[null]"), then the property is returned instead.If there is no serialized value to deserialize when the deserialization is attempted, and no default value was specified, then an empty string will be returned for string types. For all other types, a default instance will be returned by calling — for reference types this means an attempt will be made to create an object instance using the default constructor. If this attempt fails, then null is returned.
member.exception: While attempting to use the default value from the property, an error occurred. Either the attempt to convert property to a valid type failed, or the resulting value was not compatible with the type defined by .

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType
member.summary: Specifies the event type of an event log entry.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.Error
member.summary: An error event. This indicates a significant problem the user should know about; usually a loss of functionality or data.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.FailureAudit
member.summary: A failure audit event. This indicates a security event that occurs when an audited access attempt fails; for example, a failed attempt to open a file.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.Information
member.summary: An information event. This indicates a significant, successful operation.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.SuccessAudit
member.summary: A success audit event. This indicates a security event that occurs when an audited access attempt is successful; for example, logging on successfully.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.EventLogEntryType.Warning
member.summary: A warning event. This indicates a problem that is not immediately significant, but that may signify conditions that could cause future problems.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType
member.summary: Specifies the formula used to calculate the method for a instance.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.AverageBase
member.summary: A base counter that is used in the calculation of time or count averages, such as AverageTimer32 and AverageCount64. Stores the denominator for calculating a counter to present "time per operation" or "count per operation".

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.AverageCount64
member.summary: An average counter that shows how many items are processed, on average, during an operation. Counters of this type display a ratio of the items processed to the number of operations completed. The ratio is calculated by comparing the number of items processed during the last interval to the number of operations completed during the last interval.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.AverageTimer32
member.summary: An average counter that measures the time it takes, on average, to complete a process or operation. Counters of this type display a ratio of the total elapsed time of the sample interval to the number of processes or operations completed during that time. This counter type measures time in ticks of the system clock.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterDelta32
member.summary: A difference counter that shows the change in the measured attribute between the two most recent sample intervals.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterDelta64
member.summary: A difference counter that shows the change in the measured attribute between the two most recent sample intervals. It is the same as the CounterDelta32 counter type except that is uses larger fields to accomodate larger values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterMultiBase
member.summary: A base counter that indicates the number of items sampled. It is used as the denominator in the calculations to get an average among the items sampled when taking timings of multiple, but similar items. Used with CounterMultiTimer, CounterMultiTimerInverse, CounterMultiTimer100Ns, and CounterMultiTimer100NsInverse.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterMultiTimer
member.summary: A percentage counter that displays the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. Because the numerator records the active time of components operating simultaneously, the resulting percentage can exceed 100 percent.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterMultiTimer100Ns
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. It measures time in 100 nanosecond (ns) units.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterMultiTimer100NsInverse
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. Counters of this type measure time in 100 nanosecond (ns) units. They derive the active time by measuring the time that the components were not active and subtracting the result from multiplying 100 percent by the number of objects monitored.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterMultiTimerInverse
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. It derives the active time by measuring the time that the components were not active and subtracting the result from 100 percent by the number of objects monitored.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterTimer
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the average time that a component is active as a percentage of the total sample time.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CounterTimerInverse
member.summary: A percentage counter that displays the average percentage of active time observed during sample interval. The value of these counters is calculated by monitoring the percentage of time that the service was inactive and then subtracting that value from 100 percent.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CountPerTimeInterval32
member.summary: An average counter designed to monitor the average length of a queue to a resource over time. It shows the difference between the queue lengths observed during the last two sample intervals divided by the duration of the interval. This type of counter is typically used to track the number of items that are queued or waiting.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.CountPerTimeInterval64
member.summary: An average counter that monitors the average length of a queue to a resource over time. Counters of this type display the difference between the queue lengths observed during the last two sample intervals, divided by the duration of the interval. This counter type is the same as CountPerTimeInterval32 except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. This type of counter is typically used to track a high-volume or very large number of items that are queued or waiting.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.ElapsedTime
member.summary: A difference timer that shows the total time between when the component or process started and the time when this value is calculated.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.NumberOfItems32
member.summary: An instantaneous counter that shows the most recently observed value. Used, for example, to maintain a simple count of items or operations.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.NumberOfItems64
member.summary: An instantaneous counter that shows the most recently observed value. Used, for example, to maintain a simple count of a very large number of items or operations. It is the same as NumberOfItems32 except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.NumberOfItemsHEX32
member.summary: An instantaneous counter that shows the most recently observed value in hexadecimal format. Used, for example, to maintain a simple count of items or operations.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.NumberOfItemsHEX64
member.summary: An instantaneous counter that shows the most recently observed value. Used, for example, to maintain a simple count of a very large number of items or operations. It is the same as NumberOfItemsHEX32 except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.RateOfCountsPerSecond32
member.summary: A difference counter that shows the average number of operations completed during each second of the sample interval. Counters of this type measure time in ticks of the system clock.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.RateOfCountsPerSecond64
member.summary: A difference counter that shows the average number of operations completed during each second of the sample interval. Counters of this type measure time in ticks of the system clock. This counter type is the same as the RateOfCountsPerSecond32 type, but it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values to track a high-volume number of items or operations per second, such as a byte-transmission rate.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.RawBase
member.summary: A base counter that stores the denominator of a counter that presents a general arithmetic fraction. Check that this value is greater than zero before using it as the denominator in a RawFraction value calculation.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.RawFraction
member.summary: An instantaneous percentage counter that shows the ratio of a subset to its set as a percentage. For example, it compares the number of bytes in use on a disk to the total number of bytes on the disk. Counters of this type display the current percentage only, not an average over time.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.SampleBase
member.summary: A base counter that stores the number of sampling interrupts taken and is used as a denominator in the sampling fraction. The sampling fraction is the number of samples that were 1 (or true) for a sample interrupt. Check that this value is greater than zero before using it as the denominator in a calculation of SampleFraction.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.SampleCounter
member.summary: An average counter that shows the average number of operations completed in one second. When a counter of this type samples the data, each sampling interrupt returns one or zero. The counter data is the number of ones that were sampled. It measures time in units of ticks of the system performance timer.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.SampleFraction
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the average ratio of hits to all operations during the last two sample intervals.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.Timer100Ns
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the active time of a component as a percentage of the total elapsed time of the sample interval. It measures time in units of 100 nanoseconds (ns). Counters of this type are designed to measure the activity of one component at a time.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType.Timer100NsInverse
member.summary: A percentage counter that shows the average percentage of active time observed during the sample interval.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Process.NonpagedSystemMemorySize

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Process.PagedMemorySize

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Process.PagedSystemMemorySize

member.returns: The amount of memory, in bytes, the system has allocated for the associated process that can be written to the virtual memory paging file.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Process.PeakPagedMemorySize

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass
member.summary: Indicates the priority that the system associates with a process. This value, together with the priority value of each thread of the process, determines each thread's base priority level.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass.AboveNormal
member.summary: Specifies that the process has priority above Normal but below .

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass.BelowNormal
member.summary: Specifies that the process has priority above Idle but below Normal.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass.High
member.summary: Specifies that the process performs time-critical tasks that must be executed immediately, such as the Task List dialog, which must respond quickly when called by the user, regardless of the load on the operating system. The threads of the process preempt the threads of normal or idle priority class processes.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass.Idle
member.summary: Specifies that the threads of this process run only when the system is idle, such as a screen saver. The threads of the process are preempted by the threads of any process running in a higher priority class.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass.Normal
member.summary: Specifies that the process has no special scheduling needs.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessPriorityClass.RealTime
member.summary: Specifies that the process has the highest possible priority.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle
member.summary: Specified how a new window should appear when the system starts a process.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden
member.summary: The hidden window style. A window can be either visible or hidden. The system displays a hidden window by not drawing it. If a window is hidden, it is effectively disabled. A hidden window can process messages from the system or from other windows, but it cannot process input from the user or display output. Frequently, an application may keep a new window hidden while it customizes the window's appearance, and then make the window style Normal. To use , the property must be false.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Maximized
member.summary: The maximized window style. By default, the system enlarges a maximized window so that it fills the screen or, in the case of a child window, the parent window's client area. If the window has a title bar, the system automatically moves it to the top of the screen or to the top of the parent window's client area. Also, the system disables the window's sizing border and the window-positioning capability of the title bar so that the user cannot move the window by dragging the title bar.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Minimized
member.summary: The minimized window style. By default, the system reduces a minimized window to the size of its taskbar button and moves the minimized window to the taskbar.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle.Normal
member.summary: The normal, visible window style. The system displays a window with Normal style on the screen, in a default location. If a window is visible, the user can supply input to the window and view the window's output. Frequently, an application may initialize a new window to the Hidden style while it customizes the window's appearance, and then make the window style Normal.

member.summary: A state that indicates the thread is waiting to use a processor because no processor is free. The thread is prepared to run on the next available processor.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadState.Running
member.summary: A state that indicates the thread is currently using a processor.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadState.Standby
member.summary: A state that indicates the thread is about to use a processor. Only one thread can be in this state at a time.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadState.Terminated
member.summary: A state that indicates the thread has finished executing and has exited.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadState.Transition
member.summary: A state that indicates the thread is waiting for a resource, other than the processor, before it can execute. For example, it might be waiting for its execution stack to be paged in from disk.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadState.Unknown
member.summary: The state of the thread is unknown.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadState.Wait
member.summary: A state that indicates the thread is not ready to use the processor because it is waiting for a peripheral operation to complete or a resource to become free. When the thread is ready, it will be rescheduled.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason
member.summary: Specifies the reason a thread is waiting.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.EventPairHigh
member.summary: The thread is waiting for event pair high.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.EventPairLow
member.summary: The thread is waiting for event pair low.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.ExecutionDelay
member.summary: Thread execution is delayed.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.Executive
member.summary: The thread is waiting for the scheduler.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.FreePage
member.summary: The thread is waiting for a free virtual memory page.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.LpcReceive
member.summary: The thread is waiting for a local procedure call to arrive.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.LpcReply
member.summary: The thread is waiting for reply to a local procedure call to arrive.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.PageIn
member.summary: The thread is waiting for a virtual memory page to arrive in memory.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.PageOut
member.summary: The thread is waiting for a virtual memory page to be written to disk.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.Suspended
member.summary: Thread execution is suspended.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.SystemAllocation
member.summary: The thread is waiting for system allocation.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.Unknown
member.summary: The thread is waiting for an unknown reason.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.UserRequest
member.summary: The thread is waiting for a user request.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.ThreadWaitReason.VirtualMemory
member.summary: The thread is waiting for the system to allocate virtual memory.

member.name: T:System.IO.Ports.Handshake
member.summary: Specifies the control protocol used in establishing a serial port communication for a object.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Handshake.None
member.summary: No control is used for the handshake.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Handshake.RequestToSend
member.summary: Request-to-Send (RTS) hardware flow control is used. RTS signals that data is available for transmission. If the input buffer becomes full, the RTS line will be set to false. The RTS line will be set to true when more room becomes available in the input buffer.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Handshake.RequestToSendXOnXOff
member.summary: Both the Request-to-Send (RTS) hardware control and the XON/XOFF software controls are used.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Handshake.XOnXOff
member.summary: The XON/XOFF software control protocol is used. The XOFF control is sent to stop the transmission of data. The XON control is sent to resume the transmission. These software controls are used instead of Request to Send (RTS) and Clear to Send (CTS) hardware controls.

member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 1.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Parity.None
member.summary: No parity check occurs.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Parity.Odd
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an odd number.

member.name: F:System.IO.Ports.Parity.Space
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 0.

member.summary: The Carrier Detect (CD) signal changed state. This signal is used to indicate whether a modem is connected to a working phone line and a data carrier signal is detected.

member.summary: Specifies that the requested action cannot be performed on the specified file because the file is not available.

member.summary: Specifies that the requested action cannot be performed on the specified file because the file is not available or is being used.

member.summary: Specifies that the requested action cannot be performed because there is not enough space on the server.

member.summary: Specifies that one or more command arguments has a syntax error.

member.summary: Specifies that the sequence of commands is not in the correct order.

member.summary: Specifies that the server is closing the control connection.

member.summary: Specifies that the server is closing the data connection and that the requested file action was successful.

member.summary: Specifies that the command is not implemented by the server because it is not needed.

member.summary: Specifies that the command is not implemented by the FTP server.

member.name: T:System.Net.NetworkAccess
member.summary: Specifies network access permissions.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkAccess.Accept
member.summary: Indicates that the application is allowed to accept connections from the Internet on a local resource. Notice that this is a protection for the local host that uses Accept to grant access to a local resource (address/port). At the time a socket tries to bind to this local resource a permission check is performed to see if an Accept exists on that resource.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkAccess.Connect
member.summary: Indicates that the application is allowed to connect to specific Internet resources. Notice that, in the case of remote host resource, no check is performed to see that Connect permissions exist. This is because the port of a connecting remote host is unknown and not suitable permissions can be built in advance. It is the application responsibility to check the permissions of the remote host trying to connect to a listening socket.

member.summary: Defines status codes for the class.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.CacheEntryNotFound
member.summary: The specified cache entry was not found.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.ConnectFailure
member.summary: The remote service point could not be contacted at the transport level.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.ConnectionClosed
member.summary: The connection was prematurely closed.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.KeepAliveFailure
member.summary: The connection for a request that specifies the Keep-alive header was closed unexpectedly.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.MessageLengthLimitExceeded
member.summary: A message was received that exceeded the specified limit when sending a request or receiving a response from the server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.NameResolutionFailure
member.summary: The name resolver service could not resolve the host name.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.Pending
member.summary: An internal asynchronous request is pending.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.PipelineFailure
member.summary: The request was a piplined request and the connection was closed before the response was received.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.ProtocolError
member.summary: The response received from the server was complete but indicated a protocol-level error. For example, an HTTP protocol error such as 401 Access Denied would use this status.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.ProxyNameResolutionFailure
member.summary: The name resolver service could not resolve the proxy host name.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.ReceiveFailure
member.summary: A complete response was not received from the remote server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.RequestCanceled
member.summary: The request was canceled, the method was called, or an unclassifiable error occurred. This is the default value for .

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.RequestProhibitedByCachePolicy
member.summary: The request was not permitted by the cache policy. In general, this occurs when a request is not cacheable and the effective policy prohibits sending the request to the server. You might receive this status if a request method implies the presence of a request body, a request method requires direct interaction with the server, or a request contains a conditional header.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.RequestProhibitedByProxy
member.summary: This request was not permitted by the proxy.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.SecureChannelFailure
member.summary: An error occurred while establishing a connection using SSL.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.SendFailure
member.summary: A complete request could not be sent to the remote server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.ServerProtocolViolation
member.summary: The server response was not a valid HTTP response.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.Success
member.summary: No error was encountered.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.Timeout
member.summary: No response was received during the time-out period for a request.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.TrustFailure
member.summary: A server certificate could not be validated.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.UnknownError
member.summary: An exception of unknown type has occurred.

member.returns: A bitwise combination of the values. The default value is .In mutual authentication, both the client and server present credentials to establish their identity. The and values are relevant for Kerberos authentication. Kerberos authentication can be supported directly, or can be used if the Negotiate security protocol is used to select the actual security protocol. For more information about authentication protocols, see Internet Authentication.To determine whether mutual authentication occurred, check the property. If you specify the authentication flag value and mutual authentication does not occur, your application will receive an with a inner exception indicating that mutual authentication failed.

member.name: T:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.File
member.summary: Represents the types of file protocol methods that can be used with a FILE request. This class cannot be inherited.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.File.DownloadFile
member.summary: Represents the FILE GET protocol method that is used to retrieve a file from a specified location.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.File.UploadFile
member.summary: Represents the FILE PUT protocol method that is used to copy a file to a specified location.

member.name: T:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp
member.summary: Represents the types of FTP protocol methods that can be used with an FTP request. This class cannot be inherited.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.AppendFile
member.summary: Represents the FTP APPE protocol method that is used to append a file to an existing file on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.DeleteFile
member.summary: Represents the FTP DELE protocol method that is used to delete a file on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.DownloadFile
member.summary: Represents the FTP RETR protocol method that is used to download a file from an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.GetDateTimestamp
member.summary: Represents the FTP MDTM protocol method that is used to retrieve the date-time stamp from a file on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.GetFileSize
member.summary: Represents the FTP SIZE protocol method that is used to retrieve the size of a file on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.ListDirectory
member.summary: Represents the FTP NLIST protocol method that gets a short listing of the files on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.ListDirectoryDetails
member.summary: Represents the FTP LIST protocol method that gets a detailed listing of the files on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.MakeDirectory
member.summary: Represents the FTP MKD protocol method creates a directory on an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.PrintWorkingDirectory
member.summary: Represents the FTP PWD protocol method that prints the name of the current working directory.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.RemoveDirectory
member.summary: Represents the FTP RMD protocol method that removes a directory.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.Rename
member.summary: Represents the FTP RENAME protocol method that renames a directory.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.UploadFile
member.summary: Represents the FTP STOR protocol method that uploads a file to an FTP server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Ftp.UploadFileWithUniqueName
member.summary: Represents the FTP STOU protocol that uploads a file with a unique name to an FTP server.

member.name: T:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http
member.summary: Represents the types of HTTP protocol methods that can be used with an HTTP request.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http.Connect
member.summary: Represents the HTTP CONNECT protocol method that is used with a proxy that can dynamically switch to tunneling, as in the case of SSL tunneling.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http.Get
member.summary: Represents an HTTP GET protocol method.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http.Head
member.summary: Represents an HTTP HEAD protocol method. The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server only returns message-headers in the response, without a message-body.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http.MkCol
member.summary: Represents an HTTP MKCOL request that creates a new collection (such as a collection of pages) at the location specified by the request-Uniform Resource Identifier (URI).

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http.Post
member.summary: Represents an HTTP POST protocol method that is used to post a new entity as an addition to a URI.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebRequestMethods.Http.Put
member.summary: Represents an HTTP PUT protocol method that is used to replace an entity identified by a URI.

member.summary: and .

member.summary: and .

member.summary: Content can be taken from the cache after it has expired, until the time specified with this value elapses.

member.summary: For internal use only. The Framework will throw an if you try to use this member.

member.name: T:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel
member.summary: Specifies caching behavior for resources obtained using the Hypertext Transfer protocol (HTTP).

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.BypassCache
member.summary: Satisfies a request by using the server. No entries are taken from caches, added to caches, or removed from caches between the client and server. No entries are taken from caches, added to caches, or removed from caches between the client and server. This is the default cache behavior specified in the machine configuration file that ships with the .NET Framework.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.CacheIfAvailable
member.summary: Satisfies a request for a resource from the cache if the resource is available; otherwise, sends a request for a resource to the server. If the requested item is available in any cache between the client and the server, the request might be satisfied by the intermediate cache.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.CacheOnly
member.summary: Satisfies a request using the locally cached resource; does not send a request for an item that is not in the cache. When this cache policy level is specified, a exception is thrown if the item is not in the client cache.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.CacheOrNextCacheOnly
member.summary: Satisfies a request for a resource either from the local computer's cache or a remote cache on the local area network. If the request cannot be satisfied, a exception is thrown. In the HTTP caching protocol, this is achieved using the only-if-cached cache control directive.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.Default
member.summary: Satisfies a request for a resource either by using the cached copy of the resource or by sending a request for the resource to the server. The action taken is determined by the current cache policy and the age of the content in the cache. This is the cache level that should be used by most applications.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.NoCacheNoStore
member.summary: Never satisfies a request by using resources from the cache and does not cache resources. If the resource is present in the local cache, it is removed. This policy level indicates to intermediate caches that they should remove the resource. In the HTTP caching protocol, this is achieved using the no-cache cache control directive.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.Refresh
member.summary: Satisfies a request by using the server or a cache other than the local cache. Before the request can be satisfied by an intermediate cache, that cache must revalidate its cached entry with the server. In the HTTP caching protocol, this is achieved using the max-age = 0 cache control directive and the no-cache Pragma header.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.Reload
member.summary: Satisfies a request by using the server. The response might be saved in the cache. In the HTTP caching protocol, this is achieved using the no-cache cache control directive and the no-cache Pragma header.

member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.HttpRequestCacheLevel.Revalidate
member.summary: Compares the copy of the resource in the cache with the copy on the server. If the copy on the server is newer, it is used to satisfy the request and replaces the copy in the cache. If the copy in the cache is the same as the server copy, the cached copy is used. In the HTTP caching protocol, this is achieved using a conditional request.

member.summary: Satisfies a request using the locally cached resource; does not send a request for an item that is not in the cache. When this cache policy level is specified, a exception is thrown if the item is not in the client cache.

member.summary: Satisfies a request for a resource either by using the cached copy of the resource or by sending a request for the resource to the server. member.name: F:System.Net.Cache.RequestCacheLevel.Revalidate
member.summary: Satisfies a request by using the cached copy of the resource if the timestamp is the same as the timestamp of the resource on the server; otherwise, the resource is downloaded from the server, presented to the caller, and stored in the cache.

member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum length of an upload in response to an unauthorized error code.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer containing the maximum length (in multiple of 1,024 byte units) of an upload in response to an unauthorized error code. A value of -1 indicates that no size limit will be imposed on the upload. Setting the property to any other value will only send the request body if it is smaller than the number of bytes specified. So a value of 1 would indicate to only send the request body if it is smaller than 1,024 bytes. The default value for this property is -1.

member.name: T:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeDecodingConformance
member.summary: Controls how Unicode characters are interpreted by the methods.

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeDecodingConformance.Auto
member.summary: Use automatic behavior. The decoding behavior is determined by current application's target Framework. For .NET Framework 4.5 and later, the Unicode encoding decoding is strict.

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeDecodingConformance.Compat
member.summary: Use compatible behavior. Specifies that incoming data is not checked for validity before being decoded. For example, an input string of "&#xD84C;" would decode as U+D84C, which is an unpaired surrogate. Additionally, the decoder does not understand code points in the SMP unless they're represented as HTML-encoded surrogates, so the inputstring "𣎴" would result in the output string "𣎴".

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeDecodingConformance.Loose
member.summary: Use loose behavior. Similar to in that there are no validity checks, but the decoder also understands code points. The input string "𣎴" would decode into the character U+233B4 correctly. This switch is meant to provide maximum interoperability when the decoder doesn't know which format the provider is using to generate the encoded string.

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeDecodingConformance.Strict
member.summary: Use strict behavior. Specifies that the incoming encoded data is checked for validity before being decoded. For example, an input string of "𣎴" would decode as U+233B4, but an input string of "��" would fail to decode properly. Already-decoded data in the string is not checked for validity. For example, an input string of "\ud800" will result in an output string of "\ud800", as the already-decoded surrogate is skipped during decoding, even though it is unpaired.

member.name: T:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeEncodingConformance
member.summary: Controls how Unicode characters are output by the methods.

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeEncodingConformance.Auto
member.summary: Use automatic behavior. The Unicode encoding behavior is determined by current application's target Framework. For .NET Framework 4.5 and later, the Unicode encoding behavior is strict.

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeEncodingConformance.Compat
member.summary: Use compatible behavior. Specifies that individual UTF-16 surrogate code points are output as-is when one of methods is called. For example, given a string "\uD84C\uDFB4" (or "\U000233B4"), the output of is "\uD84C\uDFB4" (the input is not encoded).

member.name: F:System.Net.Configuration.UnicodeEncodingConformance.Strict
member.summary: Use strict behavior. Specifies that individual UTF-16 surrogate code points are combined into a single code point when one of the methods is called. For example, given the input string "\uD84C\uDFB4" (or "\U000233B4"), the output of the methods is "𣎴". If the input is a malformed UTF-16 string (it contains unpaired surrogates, for example), the bad code points will be replaced with U+FFFD (Unicode replacement char) before being HTML-encoded.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.GeneralFailure
member.summary: The transaction could not occur. You receive this error when the specified SMTP host cannot be found.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.HelpMessage
member.summary: A Help message was returned by the service.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.InsufficientStorage
member.summary: The SMTP service does not have sufficient storage to complete the request.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.LocalErrorInProcessing
member.summary: The SMTP service cannot complete the request. This error can occur if the client's IP address cannot be resolved (that is, a reverse lookup failed). You can also receive this error if the client domain has been identified as an open relay or source for unsolicited e-mail (spam). For details, see RFC 2505, which is available at http://www.ietf.org.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.MailboxBusy
member.summary: The destination mailbox is in use.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.MailboxNameNotAllowed
member.summary: The syntax used to specify the destination mailbox is incorrect.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.MailboxUnavailable
member.summary: The destination mailbox was not found or could not be accessed.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.MustIssueStartTlsFirst
member.summary: The SMTP server is configured to accept only TLS connections, and the SMTP client is attempting to connect by using a non-TLS connection. The solution is for the user to set EnableSsl=true on the SMTP Client.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.Ok
member.summary: The email was successfully sent to the SMTP service.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.ServiceClosingTransmissionChannel
member.summary: The SMTP service is closing the transmission channel.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.ServiceNotAvailable
member.summary: The SMTP service is not available; the server is closing the transmission channel.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.ServiceReady
member.summary: The SMTP service is ready.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.StartMailInput
member.summary: The SMTP service is ready to receive the e-mail content.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.SyntaxError
member.summary: The syntax used to specify a command or parameter is incorrect.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.SystemStatus
member.summary: A system status or system Help reply.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.TransactionFailed
member.summary: The transaction failed.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.UserNotLocalTryAlternatePath
member.summary: The user mailbox is not located on the receiving server. You should resend using the supplied address information.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mail.SmtpStatusCode.UserNotLocalWillForward
member.summary: The user mailbox is not located on the receiving server; the server forwards the e-mail.

member.summary: Encodes stream-based data. See RFC 2406 Section 6.8.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mime.TransferEncoding.EightBit
member.summary: The data is in 8-bit characters that may represent international characters with a total line length of no longer than 1000 8-bit characters. For more information about this 8-bit MIME transport extension, see IETF RFC 6152.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mime.TransferEncoding.QuotedPrintable
member.summary: Encodes data that consists of printable characters in the US-ASCII character set. See RFC 2406 Section 6.7.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mime.TransferEncoding.SevenBit
member.summary: Used for data that is not encoded. The data is in 7-bit US-ASCII characters with a total line length of no longer than 1000 characters. See RFC2406 Section 2.7.

member.name: F:System.Net.Mime.TransferEncoding.Unknown
member.summary: Indicates that the transfer encoding is unknown.

member.name: T:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus
member.summary: Reports the status of sending an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo message to a computer.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadDestination
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination IP address cannot receive ICMP echo requests or should never appear in the destination address field of any IP datagram. For example, calling and specifying IP address "000.0.0.0" returns this status.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadHeader
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the header is invalid.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadOption
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because it contains an invalid option.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadRoute
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because there is no valid route between the source and destination computers.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationHostUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer is not reachable.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationNetworkUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the network that contains the destination computer is not reachable.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationPortUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the port on the destination computer is not available.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationProhibited
member.summary: The ICMPv6 echo request failed because contact with the destination computer is administratively prohibited. This value applies only to IPv6.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationProtocolUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable, because it does not support the packet's protocol. This value applies only to IPv4. This value is described in IETF RFC 1812 as Communication Administratively Prohibited.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationScopeMismatch
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the source address and destination address that are specified in an ICMP echo message are not in the same scope. This is typically caused by a router forwarding a packet using an interface that is outside the scope of the source address. Address scopes (link-local, site-local, and global scope) determine where on the network an address is valid.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable; the exact cause of problem is unknown.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.HardwareError
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of a hardware error.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.IcmpError
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of an ICMP protocol error.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.NoResources
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of insufficient network resources.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.PacketTooBig
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet containing the request is larger than the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of a node (router or gateway) located between the source and destination. The MTU defines the maximum size of a transmittable packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.ParameterProblem
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because a node (router or gateway) encountered problems while processing the packet header. This is the status if, for example, the header contains invalid field data or an unrecognized option.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.SourceQuench
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was discarded. This occurs when the source computer's output queue has insufficient storage space, or when packets arrive at the destination too quickly to be processed.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.Success
member.summary: The ICMP echo request succeeded; an ICMP echo reply was received. When you get this status code, the other properties contain valid data.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TimedOut
member.summary: The ICMP echo Reply was not received within the allotted time. The default time allowed for replies is 5 seconds. You can change this value using the or methods that take a parameter.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TimeExceeded
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TtlExpired
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TtlReassemblyTimeExceeded
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was divided into fragments for transmission and all of the fragments were not received within the time allotted for reassembly. RFC 2460 (available at www.ietf.org) specifies 60 seconds as the time limit within which all packet fragments must be received.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.Unknown
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed for an unknown reason.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.UnrecognizedNextHeader
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the Next Header field does not contain a recognized value. The Next Header field indicates the extension header type (if present) or the protocol above the IP layer, for example, TCP or UDP.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Dormant
member.summary: The network interface is not in a condition to transmit data packets; it is waiting for an external event.

member.summary: The network interface is unable to transmit data packets.

member.summary: The network interface is unable to transmit data packets because it runs on top of one or more other interfaces, and at least one of these "lower layer" interfaces is down.

member.summary: The network interface is unable to transmit data packets because of a missing component, typically a hardware component.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Testing
member.summary: The network interface is running tests.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Unknown
member.summary: The network interface status is not known.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.OperationalStatus.Up
member.summary: The network interface is up; it can transmit data packets.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode
member.summary: Specifies the IO control codes supported by the method.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AbsorbRouterAlert
member.summary: This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ABSORB_RTRALERT constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddMulticastGroupOnInterface
member.summary: Join a multicast group using an interface identified by its index. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_ADD_MCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddressListChange
member.summary: Enable receiving notification when the list of local interfaces for the socket's protocol family changes. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ADDRESS_LIST_CHANGE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddressListQuery
member.summary: Return the list of local interfaces that the socket can bind to. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ADDRESS_LIST_QUERY constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddressListSort
member.summary: Sort the structure returned by the field and add scope ID information for IPv6 addresses. This control code is supported on Windows XP and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ADDRESS_LIST_SORT constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AssociateHandle
member.summary: Associate this socket with the specified handle of a companion interface. Refer to the appropriate protocol-specific annex in the Winsock 2 reference or documentation for the particular companion interface for additional details. It is recommended that the Component Object Model (COM) be used instead of this IOCTL to discover and track other interfaces that might be supported by a socket. This control code is present for backward compatibility with systems where COM is not available or cannot be used for some other reason. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ASSOCIATE_HANDLE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AsyncIO
member.summary: Enable notification for when data is waiting to be received. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 FIOASYNC constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.BindToInterface
member.summary: Bind the socket to a specified interface index. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_BIND constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.DataToRead
member.summary: Return the number of bytes available for reading. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 FIONREAD constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.DeleteMulticastGroupFromInterface
member.summary: Remove the socket from a multicast group. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_ADD_MCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.EnableCircularQueuing
member.summary: Replace the oldest queued datagram with an incoming datagram when the incoming message queues are full. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ENABLE_CIRCULAR_QUEUEING constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.Flush
member.summary: Discard the contents of the sending queue. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_FLUSH constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetBroadcastAddress
member.summary: Return a SOCKADDR structure that contains the broadcast address for the address family of the current socket. The returned address can be used with the method. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_BROADCAST_ADDRESS constant. This value can be used on User Datagram Protocol (UDP) sockets only.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetExtensionFunctionPointer
member.summary: Obtain provider-specific functions that are not part of the Winsock specification. Functions are specified using their provider-assigned GUID. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_EXTENSION_FUNCTION_POINTER constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetGroupQos
member.summary: Return the Quality of Service (QOS) attributes for the socket group. This value is reserved for future use, and is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_GROUP_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetQos
member.summary: Retrieve the QOS structure associated with the socket. This control is only supported on platforms that provide a QOS capable transport (Windows Me, Windows 2000, and later.) This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.KeepAliveValues
member.summary: Control sending TCP keep-alive packets and the interval at which they are sent. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. For additional information, see RFC 1122 section 4.2.3.6. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_KEEPALIVE_VALS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.LimitBroadcasts
member.summary: This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_LIMIT_BROADCASTS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.MulticastInterface
member.summary: Set the interface used for outgoing multicast packets. The interface is identified by its index. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_MCASTIF constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.MulticastScope
member.summary: Control the number of times a multicast packet can be forwarded by a router, also known as the Time to Live (TTL), or hop count. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_MULTICAST_SCOPE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.MultipointLoopback
member.summary: Control whether multicast data sent by the socket appears as incoming data in the sockets receive queue. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_MULTIPOINT_LOOPBACK constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.NamespaceChange
member.summary: Control whether the socket receives notification when a namespace query becomes invalid. This control code is supported on Windows XP and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_NSP_NOTIFY_CHANGE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.NonBlockingIO
member.summary: Control the blocking behavior of the socket. If the argument specified with this control code is zero, the socket is placed in blocking mode. If the argument is nonzero, the socket is placed in nonblocking mode. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 FIONBIO constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.OobDataRead
member.summary: Return information about out-of-band data waiting to be received. When using this control code on stream sockets, the return value indicates the number of bytes available.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.QueryTargetPnpHandle
member.summary: Retrieve the underlying provider's SOCKET handle. This handle can be used to receive plug-and-play event notification. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_QUERY_TARGET_PNP_HANDLE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.ReceiveAll
member.summary: Enable receiving all IPv4 packets on the network. The socket must have address family , the socket type must be , and the protocol type must be . The current user must belong to the Administrators group on the local computer, and the socket must be bound to a specific port. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_RCVALL constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.ReceiveAllIgmpMulticast
member.summary: Enable receiving all Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) packets on the network. The socket must have address family , the socket type must be , and the protocol type must be . The current user must belong to the Administrators group on the local computer, and the socket must be bound to a specific port. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_RCVALL_IGMPMCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.ReceiveAllMulticast
member.summary: Enable receiving all multicast IPv4 packets on the network. These are packets with destination addresses in the range 224.0.0.0 through 239.255.255.255. The socket must have address family , the socket type must be , and the protocol type must be . The current user must belong to the Administrators group on the local computer, and the socket must be bound to a specific port. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_RCVALL_MCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.RoutingInterfaceChange
member.summary: Enable receiving notification when the local interface used to access a remote endpoint changes. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ROUTING_INTERFACE_CHANGE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.RoutingInterfaceQuery
member.summary: Return the interface addresses that can be used to connect to the specified remote address. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ROUTING_INTERFACE_QUERY constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.SetGroupQos
member.summary: Set the Quality of Service (QOS) attributes for the socket group. This value is reserved for future use and is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_SET_GROUP_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.SetQos
member.summary: Set the Quality of Service (QOS) attributes for the socket. QOS defines the bandwidth requirements for the socket. This control code is supported on Windows Me, Windows 2000, and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_SET_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.TranslateHandle
member.summary: Return a handle for the socket that is valid in the context of a companion interface. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_TRANSLATE_HANDLE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.UnicastInterface
member.summary: Set the interface used for outgoing unicast packets. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_UCAST_IF constant.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel
member.summary: A value that enables restriction of an IPv6 socket to a specified scope, such as addresses with the same link local or site local prefix.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.EdgeRestricted
member.summary: The IP protection level is edge restricted. This value would be used by applications designed to operate across the Internet. This setting does not allow Network Address Translation (NAT) traversal using the Windows Teredo implementation. These applications may bypass IPv4 firewalls, so applications must be hardened against Internet attacks directed at the opened port. On Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP, the default value for the IP Protection level on a socket is edge restricted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.Restricted
member.summary: The IP protection level is restricted. This value would be used by intranet applications that do not implement Internet scenarios. These applications are generally not tested or hardened against Internet-style attacks. This setting will limit the received traffic to link-local only.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.Unrestricted
member.summary: The IP protection level is unrestricted. This value would be used by applications designed to operate across the Internet, including applications taking advantage of IPv6 NAT traversal capabilities built into Windows (Teredo, for example). These applications may bypass IPv4 firewalls, so applications must be hardened against Internet attacks directed at the opened port. On Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Vista, the default value for the IP Protection level on a socket is unrestricted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.Unspecified
member.summary: The IP protection level is unspecified. On Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, the default value for the IP Protection level on a socket is unspecified.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.HopLimit
member.summary: Specifies the maximum number of router hops for an Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) packet. This is similar to Time to Live (TTL) for Internet Protocol version 4.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IPOptions
member.summary: Specifies the IP options to be inserted into outgoing datagrams.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IPProtectionLevel
member.summary: Enables restriction of a IPv6 socket to a specified scope, such as addresses with the same link local or site local prefix.This socket option enables applications to place access restrictions on IPv6 sockets. Such restrictions enable an application running on a private LAN to simply and robustly harden itself against external attacks. This socket option widens or narrows the scope of a listening socket, enabling unrestricted access from public and private users when appropriate, or restricting access only to the same site, as required. This socket option has defined protection levels specified in the enumeration.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IpTimeToLive
member.summary: Set the IP header Time-to-Live field.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IPv6Only
member.summary: Indicates if a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family is restricted to IPv6 communications only. Sockets created for the AF_INET6 address family may be used for both IPv6 and IPv4 communications. Some applications may want to restrict their use of a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family to IPv6 communications only. When this value is non-zero (the default on Windows), a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family can be used to send and receive IPv6 packets only. When this value is zero, a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family can be used to send and receive packets to and from an IPv6 address or an IPv4 address. Note that the ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of IPv4 mapped addresses. This socket option is supported on Windows Vista or later.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.KeepAlive
member.summary: Use keep-alives.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.Linger
member.summary: Linger on close if unsent data is present.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.MaxConnections
member.summary: Not supported; will throw a if used.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions
member.summary: The enumeration defines values used in file transfer requests.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.Disconnect
member.summary: Start a transport-level disconnect after all the file data has been queued for transmission. When used with , these flags return the socket to a disconnected, reusable state after the file has been transmitted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.ReuseSocket
member.summary: The socket handle may be reused when the request completes. This flag is valid only if is also specified. When used with , these flags return the socket to a disconnected, reusable state after the file has been transmitted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.UseDefaultWorkerThread
member.summary: Use the default thread to process long file transfer requests.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.UseKernelApc
member.summary: Use kernel asynchronous procedure calls (APCs) instead of worker threads to process long file transfer requests. Long requests are defined as requests that require more than a single read from the file or a cache; the request therefore depends on the size of the file and the specified length of the send packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.UseSystemThread
member.summary: Use system threads to process long file transfer requests.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.WriteBehind
member.summary: Complete the file transfer request immediately, without pending. If this flag is specified and the file transfer succeeds, the data has been accepted by the system but not necessarily acknowledged by the remote end. Do not use this flag with the and flags.

member.summary: Represents well known WebSocket close codes as defined in section 11.7 of the WebSocket protocol spec.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.Empty
member.summary: No error specified.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.EndpointUnavailable
member.summary: (1001) Indicates an endpoint is being removed. Either the server or client will become unavailable.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.InternalServerError
member.summary: The connection will be closed by the server because of an error on the server.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.InvalidMessageType
member.summary: (1003) The client or server is terminating the connection because it cannot accept the data type it received.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.InvalidPayloadData
member.summary: (1007) The client or server is terminating the connection because it has received data inconsistent with the message type.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.MandatoryExtension
member.summary: (1010) The client is terminating the connection because it expected the server to negotiate an extension.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.MessageTooBig
member.summary: (1004) Reserved for future use.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.NormalClosure
member.summary: (1000) The connection has closed after the request was fulfilled.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.PolicyViolation
member.summary: (1008) The connection will be closed because an endpoint has received a message that violates its policy.

member.name: F:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketCloseStatus.ProtocolError
member.summary: (1002) The client or server is terminating the connection because of a protocol error.
